risinfo.chaptertitle: 20. Interviewing in Health, Medical, and Integrated Care Settings

sect1.title: Description of the Population: Healthcare Settings and Population Characteristics

sect2.title: Healthcare Settings
sect2.para: These can can include inpatient psychiatric, emergency, and acute care departments, the treatment duration of which may involve a shorter turnaround from admission to discharge. A unique feature of emergency care departments is their ability to provide acute medical care to individuals regardless of their ability to pay or demographic characteristics (Fields et al., 2001 ). Psychologists in this setting must be flexible in their treatment and consider the best approach to to care. Garcini et al. ( 2022 ) provide provide a case study of an undocumented Latinx individual and the psychologist’s role as part of the integrated medical team assisting in the treatment and care provided to the individual. This chapter highlights how psychologists are critical in short-term care settings. Psychologists facilitate access to mental health treatment, reduce mental health stigma, underscore the impact on health outcomes through psychoeducation of the relationship between physical and mental health on overall health and disease processes, address communication between the healthcare consumer and the healthcare healthcare professionals, and address the health needs of diverse healthcare consumers.

LTC LTC facilities provide care to individuals with chronic and complex medical problems that have caused barriers to their ability to engage in activities of daily living. Skilled nursing facilities (SNF) Skilled nursing facilities (SNF) and Department of Veterans Affairs community living centers (CLC) are long-term care facilities. The population characteristics of individuals receiving treatment in this setting tend to range in age, with older adults being the highest consumers due to increased longevity. At the same time, younger individuals diagnosed with traumatic brain injuries, disabilities, and chronic medical and psychological conditions make up the fastest-growing segment (Molinari et al., 2021 ). Psychologists’ roles in LTC LTC have changed drastically from the past in a limited consultation role. In addition to traditional face-to-face therapy, psychologists engage with the residents’ complete medical records, engage with additional healthcare staff, provide feedback, and make themselves available to the team and caregivers of the residents. In LTC settings, psychological and behavioral problems arise, and a psychologist can also provide an assessment and interventions based on their observations and staff reporting. Tailored behavioral interventions and alternate engagement reduce the reliance on psychotropic medications while promoting the health and well-being of both the the residents and staff.

An assisted living facility (ALF) assisted living facility (ALF) may involve minimal primary care on-site. Individuals may still independently care for themselves and receive assistance from community programs to facilitate aging in the home. In some instances, individuals may no longer have access to traditional primary care facilities due to progressing chronic medical conditions, reduced social support networks, and increased burden in traveling to traditional care facilities, as is the case for most rural-dwelling individuals. Individuals in these settings settings tend to be older and have complex medical conditions that also exacerbate mental health conditions or increase the risk for psychological disorders (Crawford et al., 2021 ). Psychologists in these settings encompass the roles in previously mentioned settings, including team-based interaction, in providing wrap-around care to the individual. A unique aspect is the additional data obtained from an in-home visit. During an in-home visit, professionals obtain additional data, observe instances of abuse, neglect, and exploitation, and, if appropriate, include the individual’s individual’s caregivers in their treatment.

In a clinic or setting setting where functional care is the priority, psychologists may target a specific problem with the patient in more short-term care rather than tending to a comprehensive, longer-term holistic approach. The approach should still be intersectional, incorporating the patient’s identity into conceptualization. For example, in primary care outpatient settings, a patient who is an older adult female may express interest in working on one specific problem, such as diminished energy. The psychologist may ask the patient about their primary source of stress and target the problem from a functional perspective rather than doing a holistic, comprehensive intake, for example, helping a patient identify that sleep is an actionable target problem for diminished energy. The psychologist can introduce a short course of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) . During the intake, the clinician may find that the individual needs to have more accurate ideas about sleep and aging, such that older adults naturally sleep less and nap more, which is not necessarily the case. Functionally, the clinician can underscore this as a misperception right right away and then introduce CBT-I as the mode of therapy.
In a clinic or setting setting in which holistic care holistic care is the primary approach, a psychologist may spend more time understanding the patient’s history, current functioning, and needs. Though they may still target specific treatment goals, holistic approaches utilize the biopsychosocial model of care and an intersectional lens more heavily. For example, using the same patient from the paragraph above, the psychologist would conduct a comprehensive intake that, in addition to sleep, may focus on additional behaviors, lifestyle, identity, and medical and mental health history contributing to the diminished energy. While the clinician may be aware that the patient holds misperceptions, they may wait to introduce these concepts until later in treatment, after building rapport and assessing all relevant factors.
